title: newManager, Marine Operations & Assistant Harbour Master - M24/...
description:
BE PART OF THE TEAM THAT

BRINGS THE WORLD TOGETHER

Job Opportunity: Manager, Marine Operations & Assistant Harbour Master (M24/22)

Join an organization that plays a critical role in Canada’s economy. At the Vancouver Fraser Port Authority, we focus on doing the incredible work it takes to become the world’s most sustainable port.


The Vancouver Fraser Port Authority is responsible for the stewardship of the Port of Vancouver, Canada’s largest and most diversified port. Our mandate as a Canada Port Authority, as set out by the Canada Marine Act, is to enable Canada’s trade objectives, ensuring goods are moved safely and responsibly through the Port of Vancouver. That means providing infrastructure and ensuring the safe and efficient movement of marine traffic and cargo within the port. It also means we carry out reviews of proposed activities and developments on federal port lands and waters to determine whether a project can go ahead without impacts to the environment and community that cannot be mitigated.


We are passionate about the work we do and what it contributes to our local communities, the region and our country. This is reflected in our values of collaboration, continuous improvement, accountability and customer responsiveness.


Be a part of a team that advances initiatives to promote economic prosperity through trade, a healthy environment and thriving communities for the future generations of Canadians. It’s a workplace where the intrinsic value of your contribution to help foster the continued growth of the Canadian economy becomes a tangible reality. Bring your unique strengths, perspectives and experiences to the port authority and join us in charting a course toward a sustainable future.


The Manager, Marine Operations & Assistant Harbour Master assists the Director, Marine Operations & Safety, Harbour Master in ensuring the safe and efficient movement of marine traffic and cargo within the port’s jurisdiction. With primary responsibility for managing the “transactional” elements (eg. day-to-day operations – response) of the marine portfolio, this position works closely with operational leadership such as the: Manager, Marine Operations & Deputy Harbour Master; Manager, Marine Operations & Fleet; and leadership of the Land Operations, Security & Emergency Management teams to ensure a safe, reliable and efficient supply chain.


The Manager, Marine Operations & Assistant Harbour Master will:


Marine Operations, Emergency Response and Regulations

  • Provide day-to-day marine operations leadership including the management and administration of anchorages and lay-by berths.
  • Oversee the assessment and permitting of special events on the water and other short term marine activities.
  • Manage the reporting and oversight of dangerous goods movements within VFPA jurisdiction.
  • Participate in the implementation and enforcement of harbour operations regulations, utilizing operational marine resources.
  • Support the management of fleet operations as required.
  • Ensure the provision of timely advice and information related to port regulations and operations to port users and stakeholders.
  • Promote safe port practices, procedures and act as a key point of contact for marine related port matters.
  • Act as Duty Harbour Master on a rotating basis and as on scene command in emergency response situations when required under the direction of the Emergency Operations Center Director or under direction of the Director, Marine Operations & Safety, Harbour Master.
  • Maintain current knowledge of potential and planned amendments to relevant regulations and make recommendations to the Director, Marine Operations & Safety, Harbour Master regarding their impact on port operations.
  • Ensure that regulations, practices and procedures of the port are observed.
  • Assist in the refinement, development and implementation of practices and procedures relevant to marine operations within the port’s jurisdiction.

Leadership and Management

  • Promote the VFPA’s health and safety program by demonstrating health and safety leadership through actions, participation in health and safety initiatives and regular safety conversations with employees.
  • Work closely with the Director, Marine Operations and Safety, Harbour Master; along with the Manager, Marine Operations & Deputy Harbour Master; and the Manager, Marine Operations & Fleet to ensure that daily marine operations and longer term port strategy are aligned.
  • Interface and liaise with the Land Operations, Security and Emergency Management teams to ensure adequate collaboration and resourcing are in place, to meet the fluctuating demands of port operations.
  • Maintain effective contacts at appropriate levels with members of other VFPA departments and members of the marine community including regulators and stakeholders, such as Transport Canada, Environment Canada, Department of Fisheries and Oceans, Canadian Coast Guard, Pacific Pilotage Authority, BC Coast Pilots, Fraser River Pilots, Chamber of Shipping of BC, Shipping Federation of Canada, Council of Marine Carriers, ship owners, ship agents along with other key stakeholders and service providers.
  • Represent VFPA in negotiations, stakeholder engagements, at conferences and conventions, and in the media as required, ensuring clear communication of the business strategy and key messages, and the presentation of a positive and professional image of the business.
  • Participate in the development of departmental plans and be responsible for the development and implementation of activities and programs designed to meet the intention of specific strategic and departmental priorities.
  • Participate as a member of various management and inter-departmental teams in the planning, implementation and management of business initiatives.
  • Plan, implement and review departmental staffing requirements for areas of responsibility, including the determination of clear position descriptions, accountabilities and reporting arrangements to optimize service delivery to all stakeholders. Liaise with Human Resources to ensure the effective selection, training and performance management of staff.
  • Manage direct reports, ensuring that team and individuals are motivated, have defined position descriptions and reporting arrangements, their performance goals are clear and actively managed and development needs are defined and addressed.
  • Participate in the planning and the review of departmental operating costs, capital costs and particularly with regard to staffing requirements, overheads, consultancy services, planned business programs and service provision.
  • Articulate and live the VFPA culture and values, set an example by modelling the required behaviours and hold others (staff and peers) accountable for their actions by identifying and acting on behaviour which is inconsistent with agreed standards and values.
  • Provide an active and positive leadership example within the wider Port community, clearly communicating VFPA’s strategy and key elements of VFPA’s business plan, ensuring VFPA’s ability to deliver improvements through influence as well as direct control.

The successful candidate will have post-secondary education relevant to the position and a minimum of five years of related marine operations experience. At least two of those years must include deep-sea sailing experience (Certificate of Competency), or an acceptable combination of education and experience. Must have extensive knowledge of the marine transportation industry, and computer proficiency in Word, Excel and PowerPoint.

The ideal candidate must have excellent leadership qualities and management skills. Must have excellent communication and public speaking skills to effectively interface with all contacts including all levels of business, government and the public to represent VFPA as a dynamic organization prepared to seize opportunities for VFPA as a world-class port. Must have a strong customer service orientation while managing a breadth of responsibilities. Must also demonstrate effective decision-making, planning and initiative, while fostering the development of all of these competencies in VFPA’s emerging leaders


WORKING CONDITIONS

Normal office conditions with occasional exposure to harbour conditions onshore and afloat.


MARINE TRANSPORTATION SECURITY CLEARANCE

The incumbent must obtain and maintain a valid Marine Transportation Security Clearance as this position is required to access restricted areas/information as defined by the Marine Transportation Security Regulations.


The Vancouver Fraser Port Authority offers a competitive compensation and benefits package including an Earned Time Off program.


The health and safety our of employees is a priority and the Vancouver Fraser Port Authority is committed to ensuring a safe workplace. Vaccinations, in combination with other preventative health and safety measures, offer the best available protection against COVID-19 and that is why port authority employees are required to be fully vaccinated against COVID-19. Providing proof of vaccination against COVID-19 is a condition of employment.


Candidates may be accommodated for this requirement if they are approved for a legal exemption; accommodation may be requested only for religious and medical reasons, or other protected grounds under the Canadian Human Rights Act. If you’re seeking accommodation to the COVID-19 vaccination requirement, please indicate your request during the recruitment process.


This work is Canadian based employment and expected to be performed from our Vancouver office location


Please note this posting will remain open until filled.

We thank all applicants for their interest, however, only shortlisted candidates will be contacted.


At the port authority, we are dedicated to employment equity and a workplace reflective of the diversity of our port community.


Learn more about us at www.portvancouver.com

title: newOperations Analyst
description:
OPERATIONS ANALYST

The Great Lakes Pilotage Authority (GLPA) is a federal Crown corporation established, pursuant to the Pilotage Act, in order to provide safe, efficient, reliable and comprehensive marine pilotage and related services in its region of responsibility. The role and objectives of the GLPA are to establish, operate, maintain and administer, in the interest of safety, efficient comprehensive marine pilotage and related services within its geographical boundaries, pursuant to the Pilotage Act.

Position Summary:

Reporting to the Chief Operating Officer (COO), the Operations Analyst is responsible for the Great Lakes Marine Pilotage Certificate Training Program and the auditing and monitoring of domestic vessels through the Great Lakes Region to ensure a safe, reliable and efficient pilotage service. The Operations Analyst analyzes various data, produces statistics, supports the operations department, and participates in management projects.

Posting number: GLPA2022-03

Conditions of Employment:

Salary from $58,000 to 87,400 per year

Performance incentive program

Scheduled for 37.5 hours per week

Group benefits paid for by the employer

Public Service dental and medical benefits

Public Service Pension Plan

Full-time, permanent position

Work location is the GLPA Head Office in Cornwall Ontario

Primary Responsibilities:

§ Document, monitor and audit all pilotage certificate holders, and all navigating officers employed by Recognized Shipping Companies.

§ Maintain communications and generate lists to the Recognized Shipping Companies regarding certificate holders, trainees, trainers and evaluators.

§ Oversee all documents that are required for the maintaining requirements for both Licensed Pilots and Pilotage Certificate Holders.

§ Generate notification letters for marine medical renewals for GLPA pilots, 3 months prior to their expiry dates.

§ Generate the applicable notification letters relating to trainer approvals, evaluator approvals, trainee approvals as required.

§ Manage the submissions of documentation and information relating to issuance of pilotage certificates.

§ Review Great Lakes Marine Pilotage Certificate Trainee Program trainee file submissions from the Recognized Shipping Companies and provide recommendations to the Chief Operating Officer.

§ Provide various reports relating to pilotage certification, the Great Lakes Marine Pilotage Certificate Training Program and vessel transits.

§ Monitor and audits at random the domestic vessel transiting in the Great Lakes Region using the established vessel transit information request process. Communicate any major issues to the Chief Operating Officer which result from the monitoring and audit process.

§ Audit on-board training programs. Develop, and maintain records of audits. Develop audit reports.

§ Audit of training courses and institutions. Develop and maintain the list of approved GLPA training facilities.

§ Provide support to the COO with the quality management system.

§ Conduct research and assist in the development of operational policies, procedures and related documents.

§ Provide support to the COO with the review of the associated Pilotage Regulations.

§ Monitor the validity and life cycle of safety equipment.

§ Provide forecasted budgets to the COO relating to the safety equipment orders (Inflatable lifejackets, floater coats, hydrostatic lights).

§ Prepare the Operations Report based on the information provided by the Operations team.

§ Perform administrative tasks relating to Apprentice Pilot training and GLPA Business approvals.

SKILLS:

§ Excellent interpersonal skills;

§ Strong ability to build and maintain positive and professional relationships with GLPA colleagues and external GLPA customers;

§ Strong diplomacy is a critical component to this position;

§ Sound judgment, initiative, organizational skills, management skills and is self-reliant;

§ Clear, precise and professional verbal and written communications;

§ Ability to analyze, plan and schedule daily activities;

§ Skilled at prioritizing tasks;

§ An aptitude for producing quality work and can work within broad scope of action;

§ Strong aptitude with computer applications, including Microsoft Office and other related database applications;

Qualifications:

Required:

§ Possess a post-secondary diploma in Maritime Studies or Business Administration and a minimum of 2 years of relevant experience.

§ Skills in project management and analysis.

§ Ability to analyze, interpret data and input information.

§ Ability to organize, multitask, prioritize, and work independently.

§ Ability to work under pressure.

§ Proficient in the use of MS Office application programs: MS Word, Excel, Outlook, Teams and PowerPoint.

§ Knowledge and experience in using database system(s)

§ Excellent verbal and written communications skills in both official languages

Preferred:

§ Presentation skills

§ Holder of ISO 9001-2008 Auditor and Lead Auditor courses.

§ Possess Quality Management Systems and auditing experience.

KNOWLEDGE:

The Operations Analyst will have a basic working knowledge of the following areas, including but not limited to:

§ Pilotage Act

§ General Pilotage Regulations;

§ Great Lakes Pilotage Regulations;

§ Canada Shipping Act, 2001 and Marine Personnel Regulations;

§ Canada Labour Code and,

§ GLPA’s Collective Agreements.

The GLPA is committed to building a skilled and diverse workplace reflective of Canadian society. We treat all employees and job applicants fairly and with dignity and respect. The GLPA uses an individual’s qualifications, skills and achievements as the basis for employment-related decisions, including hiring, promotions, compensation, benefits and conditions of employment. We promote employment equity and encourage you to complete the Self-declaration Form if you belong to one of the designated groups when you apply (Aboriginal peoples, members of visible minorities, persons with disabilities, women).

The self-declaration form is available on our website at: http://www.glpa-apgl.com/about/careers/

(Only candidates selected for an interview will be contacted.)

ANALYSTE AUX OPÉRATIONS

L’Administration de pilotage des Grands Lacs (APGL) est une société d’État fédéral créée, en vertu de la Loi sur le pilotage, afin d’offrir des services de pilotage maritime sûrs, efficaces, fiables et complets et les services connexes dans la région dont elle est responsable. Le rôle et les objectifs de l’APGL sont d’établir, d’exploiter, de maintenir et d’administrer, dans l’intérêt de la sécurité, des services de pilotage maritime complets et efficaces, ainsi que les services connexes, à l’intérieur de ses limites géographiques, conformément à la Loi sur le pilotage.

Résumé du poste

Relevant du directeur des opérations, l’analyste aux opérations est responsable du programme de formation au certificat de pilotage maritime des Grands Lacs et de la vérification et de la surveillance des navires nationaux dans la région des Grands Lacs afin d’assurer un service de pilotage sûr, fiable et efficace. L’analyste aux opérations analyse diverses données, produit des statistiques, soutient le service des opérations et participe à des projets de gestion.

Numéro d’enregistrement : GLPA2022-03

Conditions d’emploi

Salaire de 58 000 $ à 87 400 $ par année

Plan de primes incitatives au rendement

Prévu pour 37,5 heures par semaine

Prestations collectives versées par l’employeur

Bénéfices dentaires and médicales du service public

Régime de retraite de la fonction publique

Poste permanent à temps plein

Le lieu de travail est le siège social de l’APGL à Cornwall, en Ontario

Principales responsabilités :

· Documenter, surveiller et auditer tous les titulaires d’un certificat de pilotage et les officiers de navigation employés par des compagnies maritimes reconnues.

· Maintenir les communications et produire des listes concernant les titulaires de certificats de pilotage, les stagiaires, les formateurs et les évaluateurs aux compagnies maritimes reconnues.

· Fait la supervision de tous les certificats requis pour le maintien des exigences pour les pilotes brevetés et les titulaires de certificats de pilotage.

· Produire des lettres de notification pour le renouvellement des certificats médicaux des marins pour les pilotes de l’APGL, 3 mois avant leur date d’expiration.

· Produire les lettres de notification relatives à l’approbation des formateurs, des évaluateurs et des stagiaires, le cas échéant.

· Gérer la soumission de la documentation et des informations relatives à la délivrance des certificats de pilotage.

· Examiner les dossiers des stagiaires du Programme de certificat de pilotage maritime des Grands Lacs présentés par les compagnies maritimes reconnues et fournir des recommandations au directeur des opérations.

· Fournir divers rapports relatifs à la certification des pilotes, au Programme de formation au certificat de pilotage maritime des Grands Lacs et aux transits de navires.

· Surveiller et vérifier de manière aléatoire les navires de la flotte canadienne transitant dans la région des Grands Lacs à l’aide du processus établi de demande de renseignements sur le transit des navires. Communiquer au directeur des opérations tout problème majeur découlant du processus de surveillance et d’audit.

· Auditer les programmes de formation à bord des navires. Élaborer et tenir à jour des dossiers d’audits. Élaborer des rapports d’audit.

· Auditer des cours et des institutions de formation. Élaborer et tenir à jour la liste des institutions de formation approuvées par l’APGL.

· Fournir un soutien au directeur des opérations dans le maintien du système de gestion de la qualité.

· Mener des recherches et aider à l’élaboration de politiques opérationnelles, de procédures et de documents connexes.

· Fournir un soutien au directeur des opérations dans l’examen de la réglementation sur le pilotage.

· Surveiller la validité et le cycle de vie des équipements de sécurité.

· Fournir des budgets prévisionnels au directeur des opérations relatif aux commandes des équipements de sécurité (gilets de sauvetage gonflables, manteaux flottants, lampes hydrostatiques).

· Préparer les rapports d’opérations sur la base des informations fournies par l’équipe des opérations.

· Effectuer des tâches administratives relatives à la formation d’apprenti pilote et à l’approbation d’entreprises par l’APGL.

Compétences requises:

· Excellentes compétences interpersonnelles;

· Forte capacité à établir et à maintenir des relations positives et professionnelles avec les collègues de travail et les clients de l’APGL;

· De bonnes aptitudes diplomatiques sont un élément essentiel de cette position;

· Un bon jugement, de l’initiative, des compétences organisationnelles, des compétences en gestion et autonomie;

· Communications verbales et écrites claires, précises et professionnelles;

· Capacité d’analyse, de planifier et organiser les activités quotidiennes;

· Aptitude à hiérarchiser les tâches;

· Aptitude à produire un travail de qualité et à travailler dans un large champ d’action;

· Aptitude avec les outils et applications informatiques, y compris Microsoft Office, et d’autres applications de base de données connexes;

Qualifications requises

Pour être admissibles, les candidats doivent :

· Posséder un diplôme postsecondaire en études maritimes ou en administration des affaires et un minimum de 2 ans d’expérience pertinente.

· Posséder une expérience en gestion de la qualité et en matière d’audit.

· Compétences en gestion et analyse de projet.

· Capacité d’analyser, d’interpréter des données et d’entrer des informations.

· Capacité d’organiser, être multitâche, de hiérarchiser et de travailler de manière indépendante.

· Capacité à travailler sous pression.

· Maîtrise de l’utilisation des programmes MS Office: MS Word, Excel, Outlook, Teams et PowerPoint.

· Connaissances et expérience dans l’utilisation de systèmes de base de données.

· Excellentes compétences en communication verbale et écrite dans les deux langues officielles

Préférence :

· Compétences dans la préparation et délivrance de présentation.

· Titulaire des cours ISO 9001-2008 d’auditeur et d’auditeur principal.

· Expérience en tant qu’auditeur et gestion de système de qualité

Connaissance requise

L’analyste aux opérations aura une connaissance pratique de base des domaines suivants, y compris, mais sans s’y limiter:

· Loi sur le pilotage

· Règlement général sur le pilotage;

· Règlement sur le pilotage des Grands Lacs;

· Manuel de la Voie maritime, telle que publiée par la Société de gestion de la Voie maritime du Saint-Laurent;

· Loi de 2001 sur la marine marchande du Canada et Règlement sur le personnel maritime;

· Code du travail du Canada et,

· Conventions collectives de l’APGL.

L’APGL s’est engagée à bâtir un milieu de travail compétent et diversifié qui reflète la société canadienne. Nous traitons tous les employés et les candidats à un emploi de façon équitable, avec dignité et respect. L’APGL utilise les qualifications, les compétences et les réalisations d’une personne comme base des décisions liées à l’emploi, y compris l’embauche, les promotions, la rémunération, les avantages sociaux et les conditions d’emploi. Nous faisons la promotion de l’équité en matière d’emploi et vous encourageons à remplir le formulaire d’autodéclaration si vous faites partie de l’un des groupes désignés (Autochtones, membres d’une minorité visible, personnes handicapées, femmes) lorsque vous présentez une demande.

Le formulaire d’autodéclaration est disponible sur notre site Web à l’adresse suivante - Emplois | Administration de pilotage des Grands Lacs (glpa-apgl.com)

Apply online

Important messages

We are committed to providing an inclusive and barrier-free work environment, starting with the hiring process. If you need to be accommodated during any phase of the evaluation process, please use the Contact information below to request specialized accommodation. All information received in relation to accommodation will be kept confidential.

Assessment accommodation

When you apply to this selection process, you are not applying for a specific job, but to an inventory for future vacancies. As positions become available, applicants who meet the qualifications may be contacted for further assessment.

Applying to this inventory is a way to connect with hiring managers who are looking for qualified Tradespersons. Apply Today!

How does this work?

Step 1: Let us know you’re interested! Click “Apply online”.

Step 2: Tell us about you! Attach your resume and answer the screening questions in the online application.

Step 3: We will carefully review all of your qualifications. If your talent matches one of our immediate or upcoming opportunities we may contact you for further information or assessment.

Creating an environment where diverse perspectives are valued begins with self-declaration. Count yourself in and self-declare by identifying to which employment equity group(s) you belong to. In order to self-declare, please ensure to indicate this by checking off the appropriate box within the online application as part of the Employment Equity section.

Work environment

  • Are you looking for new and exciting opportunities as a Ships’ Officer or Ship’s Crew? Have you just graduated from a marine training college? Are you a serving or retired Canadian Armed Forces member? Then look no further!

  • We are seeking a Ship’s Officer and Ship’s Crew who would enjoy a challenging work experience in a dynamic environment. Embarking on this journey will provide you with a stable career in which your marine expertise is valued while allowing you to maintain work/life balance. You will work as part of a diverse team on a variety of vessels to facilitate collective objectives in support of the National Defence Team.

On top of completing valuable work that directly benefits Canada’s Pacific and Atlantic Naval Fleet, you will also enjoy the many benefits of working for the Department of National Defence (DND):
  • complementary fitness facilities and pools;
  • paid training and reimbursement of tuition for approved training;
  • dirty work pay;
  • allowances for meals;
  • allowance for Nuclear Response Team members;
  • one of the best pension plans in Canada with comprehensive dental/ medical benefits.

  • Applicants who are serving or former military, when you transition into the Federal Public Service, your pensionable time and earned vacation credits will be recognized.

Intent of the process

This inventory may be used by the Department of National Defence to fill immediate short term vacancies (90 calendar days or less than 3 month term) in various locations.

We may also use this inventory to fill future vacancies with various employment tenures (temporary and permanent), security requirements, and conditions of employment.

Your résumé.

Recent* related** marine engineering experience

_______________________________________________________________________________________

Experience working in the marine industry as a deckhand or oiler, or an equivalent military naval occupation or trade.

  • Experience overseeing vessel refits and machinery overhauls;
  • Experience in supervision;

  • Bridge Resource Management (BRM) Training Certificate;

  • Current Marine Advanced First Aid Certificate;
  • Valid Transport Canada Certificate of Competency Chief Mate, Near Coastal or higher with (STCW)
_______________________________________________________________________________________

  • Experience as a Rigger;

  • Cadet Programs (Deck or Engine)

  • Small Vessel Machinery Operator (SVMO)

___________________________________________________________________________________

  • Experience working or volunteering in a mixed public service and military environment

English essential

Information on language requirements

In support of Strong, Secure, Engaged (SSE) initiative #24, consideration may be given to the spouses or common-law partners of CAF members.

Reliability Status security clearance - Various security levels - (we will help you attain this during the hiring process)

All employees of the core public administration are required to be fully vaccinated against COVID-19, unless accommodated based on a medical contraindication, religion, or another prohibited ground for discrimination as defined under the Canadian Human Rights Act and attest to their vaccination status.

  • Must be available to work unexpected and scheduled overtime as required

Other information

Information on employment equity

title: Surveyor and Auditor - Canada
description:
Local Unit & Position Description:
DNV Maritime Region Americas is seeking a Surveyor and Auditor to join our Montreal Station.

As a fleet in service Senior Surveyor and Auditor for Montreal you will be member of a highly-qualified team of surveyors and serving the maritime industry and various ship types (e.g.: bulk carriers, containers, general cargo, tankers, lakers, passenger vessels) calling ports in Quebec and Ontario provinces.

What You'll Do
  • Conduct inspection surveys and certification of ships in service to ascertain the condition of mechanically functioning hulls, machinery, equipment, and equipage to determine repairs required for vessels to meet requirements for classification.   • You'll perform equipment maintenance, booking and scheduling, field program coordination, communications with suppliers
  • You’ll have a focus of water quality equipment and standard operating procedures, with an interest in maintaining a suite of different instruments
  • You’ll collaborate with warehouse staff in Calgary and Edmonton to manage water quality and limnology field equipment
  • You'll support on fieldwork as needed and will be travelling within Alberta and possibly across provinces
  • You’ll have opportunities to support on WSP’s growing drone water sampling program, with training provided in Canada and the US
  • You'll conduct fieldwork in a safe and collaborative environment and be able help with equipment troubleshooting and maintenance in remote areas
  • You’ll assist with office duties such as data compilation and management
  • You will always ensure health and safety policies are followed at all sites and take WSP's Life Saving rules to heart.

  • 2-5 years of experience in the environmental sector
  • A Class 5 driver’s licence
  • First aid, H2S Alive, WHIMIS, TDG, boat operators’ certificate
  • A working knowledge of the safe operation of boats and experience with operating boats and working on water
  • Drone pilot experience or an interest in training and learning this skill is an asset
  • An excellent work ethic with strong organization and time management skills
  • A detail-oriented approach with a focus on quality of work

You may also be required to undergo additional immunization to maintain a fully vaccinated status against COVID-19 whenever local Public Health Authorities recommend additional immunization.

Offers of employment for safety-sensitive positions involving fieldwork are contingent upon candidates being able to perform key physical tasks of the job as described in the job posting and interview. This may include the ability to work in a variety of environmental conditions, such as remote or isolated areas, working alone, and in inclement weather (within safe and reasonable limits).

Job Description

Pacific Pilotage Authority is seeking a Relief On-Call Launch Engineer for our Prince Rupert launch operations. This position is offered subject to the terms and conditions of the current Canadian Merchant Service Guild agreement.

Applications can be submitted via email to hr @ ppa.gc.ca. Please include your resume.

  • Starting wage is $54.52/hour (wage during training period, paid at 75%)

  • Successful candidates will be required to work shifts; a full shift is 12 hours.
  • A list of the duties and qualifications are available on request.
  • The successful individual must be available on short notice for relief opportunities.
  • Responsible to the Director, Marine Operations for pilot boat maintenance and performance of seamanship duties.

Duties

  • Performance of boat maintenance, including checking fluid/oil levels, routine and comprehensive checks of engine and deck equipment and record keeping of the above maintenance.
  • Troubleshooting of systems. Training of crew in inspection procedures and operation of various systems. Planning and co-ordination of repairs as required. Assist with development of formal procedures for operation, checks and maintenance procedures.
  • As required, performance of seamanship duties; including operation of deck machinery/appliances, look-out and watch keeping duties and basic boat husbandry.
  • Assist, as required, in the performance of pilot-transfer duties during the pilot boarding or boarding-off of a vessel.
  • Performance of marine emergency duties, including recovery of a person in the water, first-aid and the operation and maintenance of life-saving equipment.
  • Other duties related to the operations of pilot transfers and the maintenance of property and equipment belonging to the Pacific Pilotage Authority.

Requirements:

  • Valid certificates for Class Four Marine Engineer, Marine First Aid and Transport Canada Medical are a prerequisite. *Experienced SVMOs or experienced candidates with lesser marine engineer qualifications may also be considered.

  • Candidates must pass a medical screening, including drug and alcohol screening in line with a recruitment process for a safety sensitive position.
  • It is essential that the successful candidate is a reliable self-starter and team player who is able to assume responsibility for maintenance duties, work collaboratively, and maintain calm in stressful situations.

Organization

  • A federal Crown Corporation based in downtown Vancouver, the Pacific Pilotage Authority (PPA) provides safe and efficient marine pilotage services in the coastal waters of British Columbia, including the Fraser River.
  • PPA oversees dispatch and launch operations at stations in Vancouver, Victoria, Steveston and Prince Rupert.
  • A progressive employer with a mandate critical to the economy of Canada. The PPA is wholly self-funded, complex, small and nimble. PPA employs a diverse workforce of approximately 100 people.
  • PPA generates revenue through collection of Pilotage service charges paid by transportation companies that access the coastal waters of British Columbia with the assistance of licensed pilots.
  • PPA is governed by a Board of Directors appointed by the Government of Canada.
  • PPA offers a dynamic environment and competitive compensation and benefits for full-time employees, including a defined benefit pension.
  • For more information about PPA, please visit https://www.ppa.gc.ca/welcome.

If you require accommodations through the hiring process, please let us know. All information received in relation to accommodation will be kept confidential.

Pacific Pilotage Authority is committed to building a diverse workforce and inclusive work environment.

We are committed to employment equity and encourage applications from women, Indigenous Peoples, persons with disabilities and visible minorities.

title: newCommunity Relations Officer
description:
About The CMM

The Confederacy of Mainland Mi’kmaq (The CMM) is a Tribal Council representing eight, Mi’kmaq communities of mainland NS. Our mission is to proactively promote and assist Mi’kmaq communities’ initiatives towards self-determination and enhancement of community. The CMM main office is in the Millbrook Mi’kmaw Community in Nova Scotia and has over 120 Employees. The CMM’s Department of Community Services & Infrastructure is currently looking for an energetic, mature, and independent candidate to fill the role of Community Relations Officer for Mi’kmawey Green Communities (MGC).

Position Overview

Reporting to the Mi’kmawey Green Communities Program Manager, the Community Relations Officer will be responsible for but not limited to: Gathering information regarding municipal service agreements and bylaws; organizing and presenting at advisory committee meetings with community leadership, municipalities and other stakeholders; performing or assisting the Field & Marine Debris Technician with Field Duties, identifying opportunities and funding for Communities; Delivering workshops / meetings regarding recycling, waste separation, and other related topics of interest to Communities; Working in Communities on pilot projects regarding composting and in- home sorting of waste; and participation in community events.

Key Areas of Responsibility

  • Develop presentations and materials to be used at Advisory meetings and workshops.
  • Perform home visits and deliver training of Community Project Leads on in home waste sorting.
  • Develop strong relationships within communities, community leaders and community members.
  • Assist the Field and Marine Debris Technician with field related duties.
  • Update and document the network of Solid Waste Management community stakeholders for each community – both internal and external.
  • Coordinate and deliver meetings in Communities to discuss community composting and non-traditional waste pick up and other areas of interest.
  • Visit established Community Compost stations and ensure they are running smoothly.
  • Create educational materials regarding non-traditional waste and establish a pickup schedule for such items in each Community. This includes travel to Communities to assist in disposal and recording the items for diversion tracking.

title: Sensor Operator – Force Multiplier
description:
Fly with an aircraft that brings innovation to new heights.

Force Multiplier (FM) is an on-demand intelligence, surveillance, and reconnaissance (ISR) division located in Newfoundland and Nova Scotia, Canada. FM aircraft are modified, maintained, owned, and operated by PAL Aerospace, a leader in international aerospace and defence design, development, and operation of airborne surveillance aircraft, heavy maintenance checks, and software applications. PAL Aerospace is driven by technology and is proud to be a pioneer of industry-leading innovations in airborne special missions.

As an FM crewmember, Sensor Operators (SO) join a world-class team, operating advanced electronic sensor systems, aboard long- and medium-range surveillance aircraft. FM crews maintain continual readiness to operate in Canada and around the world.

Job Description:
PAL Aerospace is seeking qualified, experienced, and enthusiastic applicants for a Sensor Operator (SO) position on our Force Multiplier (FM) Team. Entry-level responsibilities include the tactical operation of Radar and EO/IR sensor systems in the airborne environment. The successful candidate will be responsible for maintaining a tactical radar picture, in-flight planning, terrain and weather avoidance, and operation of electro-optic/ infrared (EO/IR) sensor systems to detect and identify maritime, air, and land-based contacts, recording all information acquired during airborne surveillance operations.

Flying as rotational crew aboard our DHC-8-300 and B200T special-mission aircraft, individuals must be able to work independently, as well as part of our motivated, close-knit, group of professionals; working together to deliver mission outputs required by our military, government, and civilian clients.

In addition to the tactical employment of onboard sensors systems, SO’s in this role are often called upon to maintain safety-of-flight when operating IMC, often at low altitude, in the maritime environment.

Responsibilities:
Duties and responsibilities will include but are not limited to:

  • Operate sensor equipment such as airborne radar and electro-optic/ infrared (EO/IR) imaging equipment to identify airborne, maritime, and land-based contacts
    • Ensure safety of flight by providing land- and weather-avoidance instructions to the flying pilot, when operating IMC, below MSA
    • Maintain a tactical operating picture using a variety of mission management systems and equipment configurations
    • Maintain a timely and accurate record of the location, distribution, and identification of detected targets
  • Assist the TACCO:
    • Conducting pre-flight planning and brief crew and client on mission requirements and constraints.
    • Monitoring, understanding, and communicating the capabilities and limitations of the sensors and mission systems.
    • Assisting with pre-flight preparations, ensuring mission equipment is correctly configured.
    • In-flight planning and coordination, based on inclement weather and detected target disposition.
    • Record, annotate, and disseminate all information products during flight surveillance missions.
    • Participating in post-flight debriefings and reporting duties.

Career Advancement
FM SO’s can further their job opportunities by advancing to the role of Tactical Coordinator (TACCO), working with the Aircraft Captain to manage the tactical deployment of aircraft capabilities, while operating our comprehensive U/VHF, HF, LOS and BLOS communications suites. SO’s may be called upon to prepare and drop stores, such as marine markers, datum marker buoys, and air-droppable life rafts.

Additionally, SO’s may be called upon to support flight operations from the Force Multiplier Ground Support Unit (FM-GSU), as well as supporting systems integrators with aircraft configuration and modifications. Candidates with formal sensor operator training, mission command experience, and strong technical background are highly valued on our team.

Qualified candidates may be offered the unique opportunity to travel to and from the aircraft base of operations, without the requirement to permanently relocate. PAL Aerospace prides itself on being a pioneer in innovation and is looking for qualified, like-minded, adventure-seeking crew to join our growing team.

Minimum Qualifications:

  • Experience operating mission management systems in the airborne environment.
  • Minimum of 4-years experience operating airborne multi-mode radar systems.
  • Minimum of 2-years experience operating EO/IR equipment.
  • Knowledge of airborne surveillance, tactical navigation, and communications.
  • Experience in anti-surface warfare (ASuW), counter-narcotics, and search and rescue is considered an asset.
  • Experience operating HF, UHF, and VHF radios and satellite voice and data communication systems.
  • Must be able to obtain required security clearances.

Preferred Qualifications:

  • Candidates with previous military experience will be given priority.
  • Excellent CRM with experience in a multi-crew environment is preferred.
  • Experience on Dash-8 aircraft is considered an asset.
  • Experience collaborating with international clients is considered an asset.
  • Previous ISR, flight test, and instructor/ evaluator experience.
  • Effective written and verbal communications skills are a benefit.
  • Proficient in the use of various computer systems and programs.
  • Proficient with Microsoft Windows OS and baseline Microsoft Office products.
  • Holds a valid drivers license.

Physical Working Environment:

  • Able to work in an aircraft cabin environment, flying 4-6-hour missions in our smaller B200T surveillance aircraft, with 8-9-hour missions in our larger DHC-8-300 platforms.
  • Travel with the aircraft on a rotational basis for extended rotations domestically and internationally; sometimes at short notice; operating in all weather, seasons, and terrain.
  • Accommodation ranges from hotel accommodation to crew-house environments.
  • Work during early mornings, late evenings, weekends, and holidays during On Duty periods.
  • Able to meet medical testing requirements.
  • Able to swim and complete Underwater Egress Training.

Benefits:

  • Excellent work/ life balance.
  • Competitive base salary and excellent benefits package, including, medical and dental.
  • Starting salary offered commensurate with experience, skill, education, and training.
  • Review of salary upon successful completion of agreed milestones.
  • Company covers travel to/from place of residence and aircraft location, including accommodations and per diems during On Duty periods.
  • Pension Plan for full time employees.
  • Life, health, and dental insurance for full time employees.
  • Employee Stock Purchase Program for full time employees.
  • Opportunities for growth within the company.
  • Part-time and contract options available to select candidates.

All job offers with PAL Aerospace are contingent upon passing a background check and security clearance and are subject to random drug screening.

PAL Aerospace is committed to fostering an inclusive work environment that celebrates and encourages diversity, equity, and inclusion whereby individuals are recognized, supported, and respected. Candidates of all backgrounds are encouraged to apply.

Only those candidates selected for an interview will be contacted. Thank you.

title: Indigenous Program Coordinator
company: Marine Museum of the Great Lakes at Kingston
description:
The Marine Museum of the Great Lakes at Kingston seeks an Indigenous Program Coordinator with excellent research and communication skills to research, develop and deliver a pilot program for an on-the-water Indigenous-environmental experiential paddle tour. Funded by the Community Foundation for Kingston and the Area, this program will offer an opportunity for public groups to connect culturally through a shared interest and commitment to the environment, encouraging participants to adopt a two-eyed way of seeing. The Program Coordinator will join a friendly, creative and dynamic team of maritime heritage enthusiasts while developing program development, communication and research skills.

The language of work is English, French is a benefit and regional Indigenous language abilities are considered a great asset. This position is for up to 30 hours per week for a minimum of 10 weeks at $20/hour starting 2 May 2022 and offers the potential for extension on a contractual basis.

Key areas of responsibility:

  • The Indigenous Program Coordinator will work closely with the Programs and Communications Manager in the coordination of this project to ensure objectives are met.
  • Research and develop a 2-3 hour on-the-water guided paddle tour focused on interpretation through two-eyed seeing.
  • Deliver pilot tours to youth, community groups and members of the public while modifying the delivery as necessary to improve the program for different demographic groups.
  • Assist the Programs and Communication Manager with marketing and communication tasks related to the project.
  • Other responsibilities include administrative tasks relating to tour bookings, program evaluation and equipment maintenance

Qualifications:

Preferred Qualifications and Skills:

  • Must identify as a First Nation, Inuit or Métis
  • Paddle Canada Certified Waterfront Canoe Instructor or equivalent – or ability and willingness to complete certification. First Aid, Boat Safety and/or Bronze Medallion/Cross certifications an asset.
  • Must have education or experience in developing and delivering tours and/or educational programs.
  • Knowledge of Indigenous history and culture (including two-eyed seeing) and environmental science or history is an asset.
  • Experience undertaking cultural and/or environmental research.
  • Experience delivering on-the-water programs is an asset.
  • Must have excellent customer service and communication skills with youth and adults.
  • Ability to work independently or with a small team in a public environment.
  • Motivated, adaptable worker with an open mind and a positive attitude.

To apply, please email a cover letter and resume to Michelle Clarabut at education@marmuseum.ca. We thank all applicants for their interest, however, only those selected for an interview will be contacted. Deadline for applications is Thursday 5 May 2022, interviews will take place shortly after.

Additional Requirements: Paddle Canada or equivalent Waterfront Canoe Instructor certification

Reporting to the Chief Operating Officer (COO), the Operations Analyst is responsible for the Great Lakes Marine Pilotage Certificate Training Program and the auditing and monitoring of domestic vessels through the Great Lakes Region to ensure a safe, reliable and efficient pilotage service. The Operations Analyst analyzes various data, produces statistics, supports the operations department, and participates in management projects.

Posting number: GLPA2022-03

Conditions of Employment:

Salary from $58,000 to 87,400 per year

Performance incentive program

Scheduled for 37.5 hours per week

Group benefits paid for by the employer

Public Service dental and medical benefits

Public Service Pension Plan

Full-time, permanent position

Work location is the GLPA Head Office in Cornwall Ontario

Primary Responsibilities:

§ Document, monitor and audit all pilotage certificate holders, and all navigating officers employed by Recognized Shipping Companies.

§ Maintain communications and generate lists to the Recognized Shipping Companies regarding certificate holders, trainees, trainers and evaluators.

§ Oversee all documents that are required for the maintaining requirements for both Licensed Pilots and Pilotage Certificate Holders.

§ Generate notification letters for marine medical renewals for GLPA pilots, 3 months prior to their expiry dates.

§ Generate the applicable notification letters relating to trainer approvals, evaluator approvals, trainee approvals as required.

§ Manage the submissions of documentation and information relating to issuance of pilotage certificates.

§ Review Great Lakes Marine Pilotage Certificate Trainee Program trainee file submissions from the Recognized Shipping Companies and provide recommendations to the Chief Operating Officer.

§ Provide various reports relating to pilotage certification, the Great Lakes Marine Pilotage Certificate Training Program and vessel transits.

§ Monitor and audits at random the domestic vessel transiting in the Great Lakes Region using the established vessel transit information request process. Communicate any major issues to the Chief Operating Officer which result from the monitoring and audit process.

§ Audit on-board training programs. Develop, and maintain records of audits. Develop audit reports.

§ Audit of training courses and institutions. Develop and maintain the list of approved GLPA training facilities.

§ Provide support to the COO with the quality management system.

§ Conduct research and assist in the development of operational policies, procedures and related documents.

§ Provide support to the COO with the review of the associated Pilotage Regulations.

§ Monitor the validity and life cycle of safety equipment.

§ Provide forecasted budgets to the COO relating to the safety equipment orders (Inflatable lifejackets, floater coats, hydrostatic lights).

§ Prepare the Operations Report based on the information provided by the Operations team.

§ Perform administrative tasks relating to Apprentice Pilot training and GLPA Business approvals.

SKILLS:

§ Excellent interpersonal skills;

§ Strong ability to build and maintain positive and professional relationships with GLPA colleagues and external GLPA customers;

§ Strong diplomacy is a critical component to this position;

§ Sound judgment, initiative, organizational skills, management skills and is self-reliant;

§ Clear, precise and professional verbal and written communications;

§ Ability to analyze, plan and schedule daily activities;

§ Skilled at prioritizing tasks;

§ An aptitude for producing quality work and can work within broad scope of action;

§ Strong aptitude with computer applications, including Microsoft Office and other related database applications;

Qualifications:

Required:

§ Possess a post-secondary diploma in Maritime Studies or Business Administration and a minimum of 2 years of relevant experience.

§ Skills in project management and analysis.

§ Ability to analyze, interpret data and input information.

§ Ability to organize, multitask, prioritize, and work independently.

§ Ability to work under pressure.

§ Proficient in the use of MS Office application programs: MS Word, Excel, Outlook, Teams and PowerPoint.

§ Knowledge and experience in using database system(s)

§ Excellent verbal and written communications skills in both official languages

Preferred:

§ Presentation skills

§ Holder of ISO 9001-2008 Auditor and Lead Auditor courses.

§ Possess Quality Management Systems and auditing experience.

The Operations Analyst will have a basic working knowledge of the following areas, including but not limited to:

§ Pilotage Act

§ General Pilotage Regulations;

§ Great Lakes Pilotage Regulations;

§ Seaway Handbook, as published by the St. Lawrence Seaway Management Corporation;

§ Canada Shipping Act, 2001 and Marine Personnel Regulations;

§ Canada Labour Code and,

§ GLPA’s Collective Agreements.

title: Manager, Marine Operations & Assistant Harbour Master - M24/22
description:
BE PART OF THE TEAM THAT

BRINGS THE WORLD TOGETHER

Job Opportunity: Manager, Marine Operations & Assistant Harbour Master (M24/22)

Join an organization that plays a critical role in Canada’s economy. At the Vancouver Fraser Port Authority, we focus on doing the incredible work it takes to become the world’s most sustainable port.


The Vancouver Fraser Port Authority is responsible for the stewardship of the Port of Vancouver, Canada’s largest and most diversified port. Our mandate as a Canada Port Authority, as set out by the Canada Marine Act, is to enable Canada’s trade objectives, ensuring goods are moved safely and responsibly through the Port of Vancouver. That means providing infrastructure and ensuring the safe and efficient movement of marine traffic and cargo within the port. It also means we carry out reviews of proposed activities and developments on federal port lands and waters to determine whether a project can go ahead without impacts to the environment and community that cannot be mitigated.


We are passionate about the work we do and what it contributes to our local communities, the region and our country. This is reflected in our values of collaboration, continuous improvement, accountability and customer responsiveness.


Be a part of a team that advances initiatives to promote economic prosperity through trade, a healthy environment and thriving communities for the future generations of Canadians. It’s a workplace where the intrinsic value of your contribution to help foster the continued growth of the Canadian economy becomes a tangible reality. Bring your unique strengths, perspectives and experiences to the port authority and join us in charting a course toward a sustainable future.


The Manager, Marine Operations & Assistant Harbour Master assists the Director, Marine Operations & Safety, Harbour Master in ensuring the safe and efficient movement of marine traffic and cargo within the port’s jurisdiction. With primary responsibility for managing the “transactional” elements (eg. day-to-day operations – response) of the marine portfolio, this position works closely with operational leadership such as the: Manager, Marine Operations & Deputy Harbour Master; Manager, Marine Operations & Fleet; and leadership of the Land Operations, Security & Emergency Management teams to ensure a safe, reliable and efficient supply chain.


The Manager, Marine Operations & Assistant Harbour Master will:


Marine Operations, Emergency Response and Regulations

  • Provide day-to-day marine operations leadership including the management and administration of anchorages and lay-by berths.
  • Oversee the assessment and permitting of special events on the water and other short term marine activities.
  • Manage the reporting and oversight of dangerous goods movements within VFPA jurisdiction.
  • Participate in the implementation and enforcement of harbour operations regulations, utilizing operational marine resources.
  • Support the management of fleet operations as required.
  • Ensure the provision of timely advice and information related to port regulations and operations to port users and stakeholders.
  • Promote safe port practices, procedures and act as a key point of contact for marine related port matters.
  • Act as Duty Harbour Master on a rotating basis and as on scene command in emergency response situations when required under the direction of the Emergency Operations Center Director or under direction of the Director, Marine Operations & Safety, Harbour Master.
  • Maintain current knowledge of potential and planned amendments to relevant regulations and make recommendations to the Director, Marine Operations & Safety, Harbour Master regarding their impact on port operations.
  • Ensure that regulations, practices and procedures of the port are observed.
  • Assist in the refinement, development and implementation of practices and procedures relevant to marine operations within the port’s jurisdiction.

Leadership and Management

  • Promote the VFPA’s health and safety program by demonstrating health and safety leadership through actions, participation in health and safety initiatives and regular safety conversations with employees.
  • Work closely with the Director, Marine Operations and Safety, Harbour Master; along with the Manager, Marine Operations & Deputy Harbour Master; and the Manager, Marine Operations & Fleet to ensure that daily marine operations and longer term port strategy are aligned.
  • Interface and liaise with the Land Operations, Security and Emergency Management teams to ensure adequate collaboration and resourcing are in place, to meet the fluctuating demands of port operations.
  • Maintain effective contacts at appropriate levels with members of other VFPA departments and members of the marine community including regulators and stakeholders, such as Transport Canada, Environment Canada, Department of Fisheries and Oceans, Canadian Coast Guard, Pacific Pilotage Authority, BC Coast Pilots, Fraser River Pilots, Chamber of Shipping of BC, Shipping Federation of Canada, Council of Marine Carriers, ship owners, ship agents along with other key stakeholders and service providers.
  • Represent VFPA in negotiations, stakeholder engagements, at conferences and conventions, and in the media as required, ensuring clear communication of the business strategy and key messages, and the presentation of a positive and professional image of the business.
  • Participate in the development of departmental plans and be responsible for the development and implementation of activities and programs designed to meet the intention of specific strategic and departmental priorities.
  • Participate as a member of various management and inter-departmental teams in the planning, implementation and management of business initiatives.
  • Plan, implement and review departmental staffing requirements for areas of responsibility, including the determination of clear position descriptions, accountabilities and reporting arrangements to optimize service delivery to all stakeholders. Liaise with Human Resources to ensure the effective selection, training and performance management of staff.
  • Manage direct reports, ensuring that team and individuals are motivated, have defined position descriptions and reporting arrangements, their performance goals are clear and actively managed and development needs are defined and addressed.
  • Participate in the planning and the review of departmental operating costs, capital costs and particularly with regard to staffing requirements, overheads, consultancy services, planned business programs and service provision.
  • Articulate and live the VFPA culture and values, set an example by modelling the required behaviours and hold others (staff and peers) accountable for their actions by identifying and acting on behaviour which is inconsistent with agreed standards and values.
  • Provide an active and positive leadership example within the wider Port community, clearly communicating VFPA’s strategy and key elements of VFPA’s business plan, ensuring VFPA’s ability to deliver improvements through influence as well as direct control.

The successful candidate will have post-secondary education relevant to the position and a minimum of five years of related marine operations experience. At least two of those years must include deep-sea sailing experience (Certificate of Competency), or an acceptable combination of education and experience. Must have extensive knowledge of the marine transportation industry, and computer proficiency in Word, Excel and PowerPoint.

The ideal candidate must have excellent leadership qualities and management skills. Must have excellent communication and public speaking skills to effectively interface with all contacts including all levels of business, government and the public to represent VFPA as a dynamic organization prepared to seize opportunities for VFPA as a world-class port. Must have a strong customer service orientation while managing a breadth of responsibilities. Must also demonstrate effective decision-making, planning and initiative, while fostering the development of all of these competencies in VFPA’s emerging leaders


WORKING CONDITIONS

Normal office conditions with occasional exposure to harbour conditions onshore and afloat.


MARINE TRANSPORTATION SECURITY CLEARANCE

The incumbent must obtain and maintain a valid Marine Transportation Security Clearance as this position is required to access restricted areas/information as defined by the Marine Transportation Security Regulations.


The Vancouver Fraser Port Authority offers a competitive compensation and benefits package including an Earned Time Off program.


The health and safety our of employees is a priority and the Vancouver Fraser Port Authority is committed to ensuring a safe workplace. Vaccinations, in combination with other preventative health and safety measures, offer the best available protection against COVID-19 and that is why port authority employees are required to be fully vaccinated against COVID-19. Providing proof of vaccination against COVID-19 is a condition of employment.


Candidates may be accommodated for this requirement if they are approved for a legal exemption; accommodation may be requested only for religious and medical reasons, or other protected grounds under the Canadian Human Rights Act. If you’re seeking accommodation to the COVID-19 vaccination requirement, please indicate your request during the recruitment process.


This work is Canadian based employment and expected to be performed from our Vancouver office location


Please note this posting will remain open until filled.

We thank all applicants for their interest, however, only shortlisted candidates will be contacted.


At the port authority, we are dedicated to employment equity and a workplace reflective of the diversity of our port community.


Learn more about us at www.portvancouver.com

Job Opportunity: Manager, Marine Operations & Assistant Harbour Master (M24/22)

Join an organization that plays a critical role in Canada’s economy. At the Vancouver Fraser Port Authority, we focus on doing the incredible work it takes to become the world’s most sustainable port.

The Vancouver Fraser Port Authority is responsible for the stewardship of the Port of Vancouver, Canada’s largest and most diversified port. Our mandate as a Canada Port Authority, as set out by the Canada Marine Act , is to enable Canada’s trade objectives, ensuring goods are moved safely and responsibly through the Port of Vancouver. That means providing infrastructure and ensuring the safe and efficient movement of marine traffic and cargo within the port. It also means we carry out reviews of proposed activities and developments on federal port lands and waters to determine whether a project can go ahead without impacts to the environment and community that cannot be mitigated.

We are passionate about the work we do and what it contributes to our local communities, the region and our country. This is reflected in our values of collaboration, continuous improvement, accountability and customer responsiveness.

Be a part of a team that advances initiatives to promote economic prosperity through trade, a healthy environment and thriving communities for the future generations of Canadians. It’s a workplace where the intrinsic value of your contribution to help foster the continued growth of the Canadian economy becomes a tangible reality. Bring your unique strengths, perspectives and experiences to the port authority and join us in charting a course toward a sustainable future.

The Manager, Marine Operations & Assistant Harbour Master assists the Director, Marine Operations & Safety, Harbour Master in ensuring the safe and efficient movement of marine traffic and cargo within the port’s jurisdiction. With primary responsibility for managing the “transactional” elements (eg. day-to-day operations – response) of the marine portfolio, this position works closely with operational leadership such as the: Manager, Marine Operations & Deputy Harbour Master; Manager, Marine Operations & Fleet; and leadership of the Land Operations, Security & Emergency Management teams to ensure a safe, reliable and efficient supply chain.

The Manager, Marine Operations & Assistant Harbour Master will:

Marine Operations, Emergency Response and Regulations

  • Provide day-to-day marine operations leadership including the management and administration of anchorages and lay-by berths.
  • Oversee the assessment and permitting of special events on the water and other short term marine activities.
  • Manage the reporting and oversight of dangerous goods movements within VFPA jurisdiction.
  • Participate in the implementation and enforcement of harbour operations regulations, utilizing operational marine resources.
  • Support the management of fleet operations as required.
  • Ensure the provision of timely advice and information related to port regulations and operations to port users and stakeholders.
  • Promote safe port practices, procedures and act as a key point of contact for marine related port matters.
  • Act as Duty Harbour Master on a rotating basis and as on scene command in emergency response situations when required under the direction of the Emergency Operations Center Director or under direction of the Director, Marine Operations & Safety, Harbour Master.
  • Maintain current knowledge of potential and planned amendments to relevant regulations and make recommendations to the Director, Marine Operations & Safety, Harbour Master regarding their impact on port operations.
  • Ensure that regulations, practices and procedures of the port are observed.
  • Assist in the refinement, development and implementation of practices and procedures relevant to marine operations within the port’s jurisdiction.

Leadership and Management

  • Promote the VFPA’s health and safety program by demonstrating health and safety leadership through actions, participation in health and safety initiatives and regular safety conversations with employees.
  • Work closely with the Director, Marine Operations and Safety, Harbour Master; along with the Manager, Marine Operations & Deputy Harbour Master; and the Manager, Marine Operations & Fleet to ensure that daily marine operations and longer term port strategy are aligned.
  • Interface and liaise with the Land Operations, Security and Emergency Management teams to ensure adequate collaboration and resourcing are in place, to meet the fluctuating demands of port operations.
  • Maintain effective contacts at appropriate levels with members of other VFPA departments and members of the marine community including regulators and stakeholders, such as Transport Canada, Environment Canada, Department of Fisheries and Oceans, Canadian Coast Guard, Pacific Pilotage Authority, BC Coast Pilots, Fraser River Pilots, Chamber of Shipping of BC, Shipping Federation of Canada, Council of Marine Carriers, ship owners, ship agents along with other key stakeholders and service providers.
  • Represent VFPA in negotiations, stakeholder engagements, at conferences and conventions, and in the media as required, ensuring clear communication of the business strategy and key messages, and the presentation of a positive and professional image of the business.
  • Participate in the development of departmental plans and be responsible for the development and implementation of activities and programs designed to meet the intention of specific strategic and departmental priorities.
  • Participate as a member of various management and inter-departmental teams in the planning, implementation and management of business initiatives.
  • Plan, implement and review departmental staffing requirements for areas of responsibility, including the determination of clear position descriptions, accountabilities and reporting arrangements to optimize service delivery to all stakeholders. Liaise with Human Resources to ensure the effective selection, training and performance management of staff.
  • Manage direct reports, ensuring that team and individuals are motivated, have defined position descriptions and reporting arrangements, their performance goals are clear and actively managed and development needs are defined and addressed.
  • Participate in the planning and the review of departmental operating costs, capital costs and particularly with regard to staffing requirements, overheads, consultancy services, planned business programs and service provision.
  • Articulate and live the VFPA culture and values, set an example by modelling the required behaviours and hold others (staff and peers) accountable for their actions by identifying and acting on behaviour which is inconsistent with agreed standards and values.
  • Provide an active and positive leadership example within the wider Port community, clearly communicating VFPA’s strategy and key elements of VFPA’s business plan, ensuring VFPA’s ability to deliver improvements through influence as well as direct control.

The successful candidate will have post-secondary education relevant to the position and a minimum of five years of related marine operations experience. At least two of those years must include deep-sea sailing experience (Certificate of Competency), or an acceptable combination of education and experience. Must have extensive knowledge of the marine transportation industry, and computer proficiency in Word, Excel and PowerPoint.

The ideal candidate must have excellent leadership qualities and management skills. Must have excellent communication and public speaking skills to effectively interface with all contacts including all levels of business, government and the public to represent VFPA as a dynamic organization prepared to seize opportunities for VFPA as a world-class port. Must have a strong customer service orientation while managing a breadth of responsibilities. Must also demonstrate effective decision-making, planning and initiative, while fostering the development of all of these competencies in VFPA’s emerging leaders

WORKING CONDITIONS

Normal office conditions with occasional exposure to harbour conditions onshore and afloat.

MARINE TRANSPORTATION SECURITY CLEARANCE

The incumbent must obtain and maintain a valid Marine Transportation Security Clearance as this position is required to access restricted areas/information as defined by the Marine Transportation Security Regulations.

The Vancouver Fraser Port Authority offers a competitive compensation and benefits package including an Earned Time Off program.

The health and safety our of employees is a priority and the Vancouver Fraser Port Authority is committed to ensuring a safe workplace. Vaccinations, in combination with other preventative health and safety measures, offer the best available protection against COVID-19 and that is why port authority employees are required to be fully vaccinated against COVID-19. Providing proof of vaccination against COVID-19 is a condition of employment.

Candidates may be accommodated for this requirement if they are approved for a legal exemption; accommodation may be requested only for religious and medical reasons, or other protected grounds under the Canadian Human Rights Act. If you’re seeking accommodation to the COVID-19 vaccination requirement, please indicate your request during the recruitment process.

This work is Canadian based employment and expected to be performed from our Vancouver office location

Please note this posting will remain open until filled.

We thank all applicants for their interest, however, only shortlisted candidates will be contacted.

At the port authority, we are dedicated to employment equity and a workplace reflective of the diversity of our port community.

Learn more about us at www.portvancouver.com

Ship's Crew: http://www.tbs-sct.gc.ca/agreements-conventions/view-visualiser-eng.aspx?id=24#rates-sc

Closing date: 31 March 2023 - 23:59, Pacific Time

Who can apply: Persons residing in Canada, and Canadian citizens and Permanent residents abroad.

If you have experience in any of the following positions, apply today!

Possible positions could include the following:

SO-FLP-04- Barge Master
SO-MAO-02 Engineer
SO-MAO-03- Class A Vessel Pool Chief Engineer; Relief Engineer; Yardcraft Master; First Officer- Glen Tug
SO-MAO-04- Class A Vessel Pool Master
